body_text.text: Molecular mechanisms such as natural selection and genetic drift have long been known to explain the evolutionary trajectory of organisms (Kronholm et al. 2017; Darwin & Wallace, 1858) . In light of rapid adaptation, epigenetic processes have gained attention for their capability to decipher stress plasticity resulting from the production of epigenetic variants via environmental induction (Vogt, 2017; Waddington, 1953; Lamarck, 1802) . Studies have shown that genetic variation only explains partly the adaptive strategy (Gavery et al. 2018; Kronholm et al. 2017) . While adaptive evolution is accomplished by genetic changes through mutation and selection, the process is expected to take thousands of years for many species. On the other hand, epigenetic mechanisms can provide an alternative source of phenotypic change for rapid adjustments to environmental fluctuations (Liu et al. 2018) . DNA methylation, being the most-widely studied epigenetic modification has been proposed to be an important mechanism of gene regulation in response to external environmental stresses (Thiebaut et al. 2019) . Stress exposure sets a series of functionally relevant modifications in the genome without changing the underlying original sequence of DNA (Eirin-Lopez & Putnam, 2019) , affecting gene activity through adding or removing a methyl group to the DNA cytosine (Suzuki & Bird, 2008; Song et al. 2005) . DNA methylation is therefore a pivotal mechanism to understand stress plasticity in the face of changing climate that includes the rising carbon dioxide (CO ) level in marine habitats (Fox et al. 2019) .

The unprecedented increase rate of CO level in the ocean is one of the prominent environmental stressors for many calcifying organisms in marine ecosystem. The phenomenon of nearly one-third of CO emission of anthropogenic sources soaked into the ocean resulting in a shift in seawater carbonate chemistry towards a reduced pH environment is termed as ocean acidification (OA) (Caldeira & Wickett, 2003) . As compared to open oceans, the estuarine and coastal regions experienced more land and anthropogenic disturbance and thus are highly sensitive to OA (Bauer et al. 2013) . Response of calcifying marine invertebrates to OA, including edible oyster species, appears to be highly species-specific. For instance, early-stage larvae of Eastern oysters (Crassostrea virginica) showed no significant differences in shell growth between control (pH7.9/pCO = 803 µatm) and low pH treatment (pH7.5) (Boulais et al.

Globler & Talmage 2014). In contrast, Suminoe oysters (Crassostrea ariakensis) and Sydney Rock oysters (Saccostrea glomerata) showed hindered larval shell growth with a decrease in 0.3 pH difference from control condition (Miller et al. 2009; Watson et al. 2009) . Larvae of Pacific oyster (Crassostrea gigas) from the Yellow Sea had reduced metabolic and clearance rates but displayed higher shell growth rate after settlement under pH7.4 compared to pH8.1 (Ginger et al. 2013) . Larvae of the Hong Kong oyster (Crassostrea hongkongensis), which is an estuarine species, showed no significant delay in calcification or shell growth rates in response to low pH 7.4 when compared to control pH 8.1 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Page No. 4 (Dineshram et al. 2013) . Although few recent studies have shown the ability of many terrestrial organisms such as mammals (Rolland et al. 2018) and plants (Zlotorynski, 2019; Vannier et al. 2015) to rapidly adapt to external stresses through epigenetic mechanisms, existence of similar mechanisms is scarce in marine invertebrates, especially Mollusca. Therefore, exploration of DNA methylation changes and associated epigenetic modifications as a key biological process linked to stress and phenotypic plasticity could help to explain why some oyster species are resilient to OA.

DNA methylation can be triggered by the environmental stresses and is present in calcifying marine organisms (Hoffmann, 2017) such as corals (Liew et al. 2018; Torda et al. 2017) and shellfishes including mussels (Arduna et al. 2018; Chin, 2018) and oysters (Venkataraman et al. 2020; Gavery & Roberts, 2010) . The availability of an annotated genome from C. gigas (Zhang et al. 2012) allows an opportunity of inter-species mapping and a comprehensive analysis of gene interactions and pathways of a closely related oyster species. Recent studies have described DNA methylation patterns in the C. gigas genome, with methylation level varying significantly across different functional categories of genes (Gavery & Roberts, 2010) . These pioneering DNA methylation studies in oysters have focused on developmental stages such as gametes and early larvae (Wang et al. 2014; Olson & Roberts, 2014; Rivière et al. 2017) , spats (Rivière et al. 2017; Zhang et al. 2018) , as well as adult tissues such as gill (Gavery & Roberts, 2014; Rivière , 2014) and mantle (Wei et al., 2018; Song et al., 2017) . In particular, DNA methylation patterns correspond to different functional gene transcriptions that control reproductive (2-8 cells) and post-metamorphosis (spats) stages (Rivière et al. 2017) . DNA methylation on the exon level was found to be associated with mRNA expression in marine invertebrates (Flores et al. 2012) including C. gigas mantle tissue, suggesting that alternative splicing could be affected during transcription (Song et al. 2017 ).

In C. gigas male gamete tissue, 15% of 7.6 million CpG sites was methylated in intragenic regions, where methylation and expression were found positively correlated in genes bodies and promoter regions (Olson & Roberts, 2014) .

Not only does DNA methylation mediate rapid adaptive response to environmental stressors, but organisms could also use this mechanism to quickly respond to environmental cues and metamorphose in optimal habitats. Metamorphosis involves transformation with regards to physiological and morphological body changes prepared for a species such as the invertebrates to transit from planktonic to benthic adult phases (Holstein & Laudet, 2014) . Consequently, modification in regulating gene expression is expected. A previous study has shown that sea lamprey (Petromyzon marinus) exhibited differentially methylation pattern in genes related to morphogenesis, water balance and osmotic homeostasis, in response to environmental stressors (Covelo-Soto et al. 2015 ). Significant differences in brain methylation pattern was found in European eels (Anguilla Anguilla L.) linking to morphological J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Page No. 5

changes (Trautner et al. 2017) . In oysters, the start of metamorphosis is signaled by development of a foot and a pigmented eyespot on a larval shell, of which the foot is required to attach on a substrate in response to microbial biofilm cues (Tamburri et al. 1992) to indicate that pediveliger larvae are competent for attachment. To date, data attributing DNA methylation to metamorphosis in oysters are limited. Wang et al (2014) reported marked difference in the expression level of DNA methylation related gene, DNMT3 of C. gigas pediveliger in comparison to other early developmental stages. Indeed, differentially methylated regions, especially the higher proportion of methylation in exons than introns were found highly regulated in C. gigas spats during post-metamorphosis (Rivière et al. 2017) . Investigating into the potential role of DNA methylation in oyster metamorphosis is therefore crucial especially in the face of unprecedented OA rates.

Although information on the effect of OA on DNA methylation in calcifying marine invertebrates is limited, a recent study reported an impact of high pCO 2 (~2550 µatm) on the gonad tissue of C. virginica, where a majority of differentially methylated loci were in exons and the rest in intron (Venkataraman et al. 2020 ). Similarly, Putnam et al. (2016) found two-fold increase in DNA methylation level and discrimination capacity in metabolic profiles of a scleractinian coral species, P. damicornis at low pH (7.6 -7.35) as compared to ambient (7.9-7.65) condition, corresponding to a reduced calcification rate.

The role of DNA methylation as rapid adaptive response in oyster larvae under OA remains unknown despite the fact that such information could improve the understanding of sustained adaptation strategies in marine bivalves, especially at its critical developmental stages. Here, we seek to fulfill the knowledge gap by answering 1) how oyster larvae changes their DNA methylation pattern in response to OA, and, 2) how larval metamorphosis and growth rates are related to OA-induced differential methylation pattern.

This study represents the first controlled experiment to determine the extent of changes in DNA methylation in response to OA at the time of larval metamorphosis in one of the commercially important estuary edible oyster species, C. hongkongensis.

Adult Hong Kong oyster, the C. hongkongensis (>2 years old) were collected from an oyster aquaculture farm in Guangxi area, China. They were cleaned, scrubbed, and subsequently acclimated for 20 days in the oyster commercial hatchery "Zhanjiang Haixiang Aquatic" located near the estuary of Zhanjiang, China. Adults were fed adtum libido with a mix of Isochrysis sp. and Chetoceros sp. and conditioned at a salinity of 16 ppt to match conditions at the collection site. Seawater supply was filtered through a combination of fine and coarse sands with ultraviolet light. After acclimation, adults were introduced into a tank filled with cold (5-10 o C) and warm (28 -30 o C) water cycling to stimulate spawning. Fertilization of sperm and eggs pooled from a mix of >100 male and female oysters in the tank took place after a few hours of spawning. Fertilized embryos were sieved out using nylon mesh (25µm) to rinse excessive sperm and cultured in an enclosed pond (10000 L) for 24 hours. Oyster fertilization and embryogenesis in general are affected by reduced pH, which result in the production of heterogeneously sized D-larvae with varying degree of impairment (Barros et al. 2013; Thiyagarajan & Ko, 2012; Kurihara et al. 2007) . Hence, D-shape trochophore larvae with more or less similar shell size were used to increase chance of synchronous larval development. Similar sized (~70µm) D-shape larvae were obtained by filtering with a nylon mesh (65µm) and were used for the following experiment.

The impact of CO 2 -induced ocean acidification stress on larval substratum choice and DNA methylation patterns of C. hongkongensis pediveliger larvae was examined by raising D-larvae at two different pH conditions, which served as proxy of partial pressure of CO 2 level. The two treatments, pH (NBS) 8.1 (352 µatm) was served as control and the decreased pH 7.4 (2090 µatm) as ocean acidification treatment group.
body_text.section: Experimental design -larval culture and CO 2 perturbation

body_text.text: Each treatment had four biological replicate tanks. To be ecological relevant, the decreased pH level was selected due to the estuarine habitat where C. hongkongensis lives in a highly fluctuating pH environments by as much as 0.6 pH units from the global average level due to river run o and microbial respiration in addition to the open ocean's ocean acidification projection (Environmental Protection Department, 2016; Pörtner et al. 2014) . The low pH 7.4 level to represent OA treatment has also been used for the estuarine species C. hongkongensis in our previous studies (Meng et al. 2019; Dineshram et al. 2013; 2014) . Aliquots of D-shape veliger larvae were randomly distributed into a total of eight black fiberglass-reinforced plastic tanks (500L) with a starting larval density of ~12 individual ml -1 . Larvae were allowed to grow in these culture tanks until a visible eye-spot and foot were developed, called pediveliger stage. Throughout the culture period, larvae were fed adtum libido with log-growth phase (20-70 x10 -5 cells ml -1 ) algal culture of Isochrysis sp. for the first few days and a mixed of Isochrysis sp. and To obtain the desired treatment pH level, filtered seawater in the culture tanks were bubbled with CO 2 enriched air. The bubbling of CO 2 enriched air in each treatment tanks was adjusted using the adjustable flow meter (Cole-Parmer, USA) mixed with ambient air generated using an air compressor.

body_text.text: The bubbling of ambient air into the seawater for control pH tanks was obtained without the mix of CO 2 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Page No. 7 enriched air. In addition to pH, other physio-chemical water quality parameters such as seawater temperature and salinity were recorded. Daily pH and temperature values were recorded using Mettler Toledo portable pH meter and salinity was measured using a dual-scale 0-100 PPT refractometer (Bragg & Co.). The pH meter was calibrated using NBS buffers. Seawater (50ml) from the culture tanks was subsampled every 3 to 4 days during water change and preserved using 250 mM mercuric chloride (20 µL) for total alkalinity (TA) analyses using an Alkalinity Titrator (AC-A2, Apollo SciTech's Inc., U.S.) (Zeebe et al. 2008) . The measured parameters including temperature, salinity, pH and total alkalinity were used to calculate carbonate system parameters such as the aragonite saturation states and pCO 2 concentration in each experimental unit using the CO 2 SYS program with the equilibrium constants K 1 , K 2 and KSO 4 (Millero et al. 2006; Dickson & Millero, 1987) . Relative total shell length of the larval samples (n=20) from each replicate culture tanks were measured at five different time points (Day 1, 5, 11, 17 and 21) using an optical microscope magnification (x10). ANOVA was used to evaluate the effect of low pH on the larval growth rate.
body_text.section: Experimental design -larval culture and CO 2 perturbation

body_text.text: Larval attachment choice between a suitable habitat, i.e. biofilm cues, and a control, i.e. clean polystyrene dish surface without biofilm, was tested according to the choice bioassay procedure in still water according to Harder et al. (2001) . A bioassay test-vessel was constructed by connecting two dishes (i.e. only bottom side of Falcon # 1006 Petri dishes) in a single unit using parafilm. There were nine vessels per treatment, i.e. 3 biological replicates x 3 technical replicates per tank. The bottom part of the petri dish was pre-immersed in filtered seawater for a week to form a biofilm cues on them and a clean dish bottom used as control. Irrespective of treatment, at 21 days post-fertilization, a majority (>70%) of larvae developed a visible eye-spot and foot in each culture tanks. These competent larvae were sieved out using 300 µm-mesh and used for the bioassay. About 100 larvae were introduced into each vessel and then sealed using parafilm. Vessels were allowed to be floating and partially immersed in respective larval culture tanks and treatment conditions. After 24 hours of incubation, the number of attached larvae on both sides of the vessel, as well as the swimming ones, were enumerated. The effect of pH on percentage of total larval attachment and metamorphosis was tested using one-way ANOVA followed by post hoc tests. Specifically, G likelihood-ratio test was used to determine the statistical significance of the larval choice between a biofilmed and a control substratum from the larval attachment. Pediveliger larvae of similar size from each culture tanks were briefly and gently washed with deionized water to removed salt and other small particles adhered on larvae, then snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 o C. Each sample comprised 8 to 12 x10 individuals subsampled from a larval population of about 4 x 10 6 larvae ml -1 at 21 days post-fertilization. In total, there were samples (3 biological replicates and 2 pH treatments). Genomic DNA was extracted using TIANamp Marine Animals DNA Kit (Tiangen Biotech). DNA concentration and integrity were measured by NanoDrop (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and agarose gel electrophoresis, respectively.
body_text.section: Larval metamorphosis and habitat choice bioassay

body_text.text: The libraries were constructed following the protocol from Wang et al. (2015) , beginning with digesting DNA (200 ng) with 4 U of the enzyme LpnPI (NEB) for h at 37 o C (Boers et al. 2018). Subsequently, the adaptors were ligated to the DNA fragments by combining 5 µl of digested DNA with 10 µl of a ligation master mix containing 0.2 µM each of two adaptors, 1 mM ATP and 800 U T4 DNA ligase (New England Biolabs, NEB). Ligation was carried out at o C for 12 h. Then, ligation products were amplified, and PCR products were subjected to 8% polyacrylamide gel. Bands of approximately 100 bp were excised from the polyacrylamide gel, and the DNA was diffused from the gel in nuclease-free water for 12 h at 4 o C. Sample-specific barcodes were introduced by PCR with platform-specific barcode-bearing primers. Each 20 µl PCR contained 25 ng of gel-extracted PCR product, 0.2 µM of each primer, 0.3 mM dNTP, 1×Phusion HF buffer and 0.4 U Phusion high-fidelity DNA polymerase (NEB). PCR products were purified using QIAquick PCR purification kit (Qiagen) and then pooled for pair-end sequencing (2×150bp) of 10X coverage per sample using the Illumina Hiseq X Ten platform.

Raw reads were first subject to quality filtering and adaptors trimming. Reads containing ambiguous bases (N), poor quality (15% nucleotide positions with a Phred quality < 30) or without LpnPI restriction sites were removed by a custom script in Perl (Supplementary material S1). The high-quality reads were subsequently aligned against the genome of C. gigas (Zhang et al. 2012) , a closely related sister species to C. hongkongensis using Bowtie 2 (version 2.3.4.1) with parameter set to --no-unal mode and filter to remove output that did not meet matching requirements (Langmead & Salzberg, 2012 was determined using the normalized read depth RPM (reads per million, RPM = (read coverage per site/high quality reads per library) ×1,000,000). P value <0.05 and foldchange > 2 were set as the threshold for significantly differential sites or genes by using the R package DESeq (R version 3.0.1) (Anders & Huber, 2010) . GO enrichment analysis and KEGG pathway enrichment analysis of the differential methylation sites or genes were performed in R programming language based on a hypergeometric distribution (Supplementary material S3).

The pH values throughout maintaining the larval cultures were significantly different between the control and low pH tanks at pH 8.12 ± 0.04 and pH 7.40 ± 0.04, respectively (ANOVA, pH, F 1,166 =17681, p < 0.01). However, no significant differences were found in temperature, salinity or total alkalinity (ANOVA, temperature, F 1, 166 =0.986, p > 0.05; salinity, F 1,86 =2.205, p > 0.05; total alkalinity, F 1,86 =0.21, p > 0.05).

The daily pH measurements and carbonate system in different pH treatment culture tanks were reported in Supplementary Figure S1 and Table S1 , respectively. These data showed stable CO perturbation during the entire period of larval development that allowed larval samples collected from the present experiment suitable to investigate the effect of low pH and associated ocean acidification process on larval habitat selection at the time of metamorphosis and associated changes in DNA methylation pattern.

The specific growth rate of C. hongkongensis larvae under pH 8.1 as controlled ambient hatchery condition at 0.077 x10 mm day -1 showed no significant difference as compared to low pH 7.4 treatment group, 0.086 x10 3 mm day -1 (ANOVA, F 1,6 =4.9075, p > 0.05) (Supplementary Figure S2) . On Day 11, the larvae showed significantly (p <0.05) smaller shell growth length under pH 7.4 in comparison to pH 8.1 group (Figure 1; Supplementary Figure S3 ). The percentage of attached C. hongkongensis pediveliger larvae under pH 7.4 were significantly higher than the pediveligers raised under control condition, pH 8.1, at 39% and 13% ( Figure 2 ) (ANOVA, F 1,4 =12.039, p < 0.05). In the presence of biofilm on substrates for the induction of larval attachment, the attached pediveliger larvae raised under pH 7.4 increased by twofold as compared to pH 8.1 control group, reporting 424 (29%) and 608 (13%), respectively of the (Figure 3 ). In the absence of biofilm, the number of attached larvae in pH 7.4 increased by nearly fifteen-fold as compared to the control group, 14 (0.6%) and 230 (10%), respectively. Overall, pH 7.4 treatment showed an increased trend of attached larvae in the presence and absence of biofilm as compared to those attached larvae from pH 8.1 control group (Figure 3) . According to G likelihood-ratio test results, a majority of pediveliger larvae raised at control pH 8.1 were able to select the optimal "biofilmed" habitat or substratum when compared to sub-optimal "non-biofilmed" clean substratum in a choice bioassay (Table 1 ). In contrast, over 1/3 larvae raised from the low pH 7.4 treatment failed to select the biofilmed surbstatum over non-biofilmed sumbstratum (Table 1 and    Supplementary Table S2 ).

A total of 214665 methylated sites were detected from cleaving 8 different combinations of methylated CpG sites by using LpnPI restriction enzyme (Supplementary Table S3 ). The methylated CpG sites included GCGC, CCGG, CCGC, ACGG, TCGG, CCGT, CCGA, and GCGG were identified with at least one read count from the detected enzymatic cleavage from three biological replicates of control and low pH treatment groups. Overall, methylated sites were highly concentrated in exon as compared to other gene regions such as the intron, intergenic and 5' upstream of a gene body regardless of low pH treatment (Supplementary Figure S4) .

body_text.text: Majority of the methylated sites predicted by the GO annotation could occur in the integral component of membrane, Golgi apparatus, cytoplasm, nucleus and cytosol. Cytosol was predicted the only enriched cellular component for hypo-methylation while Golgi apparatus enriched only for hyper-methylation ( Figure 6 ). Nearly 12% of the differentially methylated genes had no annotation and were classified with unknown function (Table 2 ).

body_text.text: In general, the total number of hypermethylated and hypomethylated loci were composed of a ratio 1:1 at 48.4% and 51.6%, respectively (Figure 7 ). Of the differentially methylated genes, 78.5 % of the loci concentrated in exons while the rest spanned across other regions inclusive of intron, intergenic, untranslated regions of 5' UTR and 3' UTR, and 5' upstream of the genes. Differentially methylated loci in the exon and other gene regions respectively comprised 43.8% and 7.8% from hypermethylation, and 34.6% and 13.8% from hypomethylation. Out of all the exon-concentrated loci, 25.4% of them were uncharacterized proteins as opposed to a higher percentage, 53% were characterized proteins, accounting for a difference of 27.6%. In contrast, lower percentage, 8.5% of the uncharacterized proteins were found in exon region as compared to 11.5% of characterized proteins, accounting for 3% difference.

Based on larval growth and metamorphosis results, C. hongkongensis pediveliger larvae were resilient and robust to near-future OA level at pH 7.4 despite a significant delayed growth during the mid-larval culture period (Figure 1) . The observed resilience in C. hongkongensis contrasts with other calcifying marine organisms such as corals (Nakamura et al. 2011) , sea urchins (Stumpp et al. 2012) , and other oyster species that showed negative (Watson et al. 2009; Miller et al. 2009) and no difference (Timmins-Schiffman et al. 2014) in larval growth impacts, which highlights species-specific pattern of tolerance in marine invertebrates under low pH and increased CO level. C. hongkongensis, the endemic estuary oyster species may have developed a physiological capacity to regulate the internal acid-base homeostasis and metabolism to face against the demand of low pH stress, especially since the larvae were actively feeding and acclimated to the desired pH condition for several weeks (Parker et al. 2013 ) and hence explained the higher growth and attachment rate.
body_text.section: Larval competence for metamorphosis in response to low pH

body_text.text: Planktonic larvae of marine invertebrates such as the cnidarians (Wahab et al. 2014 ) and bivalves (Tamburri et al. 2008 ) attach on substrate surface and metamorphose in response to microbial biofilms. In light of higher larval attachment trend under pH 7.4, we found nearly 1/3 of the C. hongkongensis larvae attached on substrate in non-biofilmed substratum (Figure 3 ). This however needs to be interpreted with caution given the pooled likelihood-ratio G value for pH 7.4 treatment was non-heterogeneous (Supplementary Table S2 ). Previous studies have shown a wide array of inductive chemical signals from the bacteria that induced larval attachment (Kegler et al. 2017; Tebben et al. 2011) with comparatively smaller percentage of attachment in the absence of biofilm (Freckelton et al. 2017) . We hypothesize that the attachment substrate, polystyrene dish surface along with microbial biofilm may be positively influenced by low pH condition in a way to induce better larval attachment conditions (Hassenrück et al. 2017 ). Nevertheless the modulating effect of OA triggered by low pH on the inherent interaction between microbial biofilm and attaching larvae is yet to be explored in OA research. Further studies are required to enhance the understanding of low pH on biofilm choice to better explain the mechanism behind the larval selection. Our CpG methylation results helped in the identification of differentially methylated sites in response to ocean acidification and also shown the extent of OA effects at DNA level that could lead to altered larval growth and metamorphosis. A group of eight known Ras-and calcium-binding related proteins including sodium/potassium/calcium exchanger 3 (NCKX3), and ras-GEF domain-containing family member 1B associated with cytoskeletal organization and signal transduction were differentially methylated, suggesting an increased demand for protein trafficking along actin filaments and cytoskeletal dynamics under the effect of ocean acidification (Lee & Dominguez, 2010; Baelen et al. 2004) . Genes related to NCKX3, which was hypomethylated at exon level, such as sodium/potassium/calcium exchanger and other related calcium-binding genes were found to transcribe in pearl oyster (Pinctada fucata) under low pH 7.8 as to the control pH 8.1 (Li et al., 2016) . Despite the discrepancy of the differences in oyster species and reduced pH level between the two studies, DNA methylation on the exon level in NCKX3 may imply an expression at a transcriptional level. A previous study reported by Dineshram et al. (2013) found a downregulation trend of similar ras-related proteins such as Rab-8A and RAB8A and calcium binding proteins on a proteome level from the larval tissue of C. hongkongensis pediveliger larvae under low pH 7.6.

body_text.text: Oxidative stress related genes, cytochrome c oxidase assembly factor 7 -like and serine/threonine-protein kinase pim-3 were differentially methylated, possibly suggesting a heightened demand for energy to adapt to ocean acidification stress. Protein ubiquitination, which can be activated by an increase in oxidative damage (Flick & Kaiser, 2012) These morphological changes were evidenced by the hypermethylation of caspase 7-like, a gene that play a role in apoptosis to maintain normal tissue and organ development and homeostasis (Lamkanfi & Kanneganti, 2011) , and Ia-related protein 6-like, a gene related to mRNA binding for ciliogenesis (Manojlovic et al. 2017) in response to ocean acidification. Previous studies have shown caspases expression in larval metamorphosis of C. angulata (Yang et al. 2015; Qu et al., 2014) and adult C. gigas (Qu et al. 2014) where the association of apoptotic pathways and DNA methylation were closely linked (Meng et al. 2011) . The differential methylation in these genes under the impact of reduced pH may likely be associated with the higher larval attachment of C. hongkongensis. Several genes that involved in the capability to respond to external microbial cue such as protein draper, and immune response related to phagocytosis of apoptotic cells, cell adhesion and motility (Ohno et al. 2016 ) such as multiple epidermal growth factor-like domain protein 10 (4.42; 0.02) were found hyper-methylated in response to ocean acidification. The epigenetic mechanism of increased number of methyl groups of cytosine from these genes may be suggesting a link between DNA methylation and the influence of biofilm on attachment rate without going through gene expression changes. However, this hypothesis needs to be tested explicitly in future experiments.

body_text.text: A higher concentration of CH group was found mainly in the exon region of cytoskeletal and signal system-, oxidative stress-, and metamorphosis-related genes while half the total number of known loci related to amino acid and lipid, and carbohydrate metabolic process was found in intron and intergenic regions. Differential methylation in the exon region may exert an influence on gene expression to regulate the specific tissue or cells to cope against low pH condition. The exon element may have been activated by DNA methylation to enhance the expression of useful isoforms. Previous studies have revealed that DNA methylation affects alternative splicing and gene expression (Shayevitch et al. 2018; Song et al. 2017) , where DNA methylation at exon region was positively associated with mRNA transcription in C.

gigas. This is consistent with other invertebrates (Flores et al. 2012 ) such as honey bee (Lyko et al. 2010) and wasp (Park et al. 2011) . Transcriptions of the related genes such as sodium/potassium/calcium exchanger, ubiquitin-protein ligase and caspases reported from closely related oyster species including C.

gigas (Dineshram et al. 2015; Qu et al. 2014) , C. angulata (Yang et al. 2015) and P. fucata (Li et al. 2016) were found differentially methylated in the present study. In contrast, DNA methylation of intron may impede the binding of transcriptional proteins to the gene and results in repression. Studies in humans showed that hyper-methylation in a gene promoter repressed gene expression (Lim et al. 2017; Silva et al. 2013; Bird, 1986) while in gene bodies, hyper-methylation enhances transcription of genes (Laurent et al., 2010) . DNA methylation of the first intron was found to be inversely associated with gene expression in tissues from vertebrates as well as invertebrates such as European sea bass (Dicentrarchus labrax), model pufferfish (Tetraodon) and frog (Xenopus) (Anastasiadi et al. 2018; Rose, 2008) . It should be noted that DNA methylation landscape and presumed functionality is different in marine invertebrates compared to vertebrates. For instance, vertebrates displayed genome-wide methylation while invertebrates, including representative from molluscs displayed fractional methylation (Tweedie et al. 1997) .

Together these data suggest a more detailed study to quantify the number of methylated sites on each differentially methylated genes along with transcriptome data, as well as with the different type and length of exon within the gene bodies in order to properly determine the association of DNA methylation on exon-level and transcription of genes of C. hongkongensis in response to OA. Epigenome encompasses mitotically and meiotically heritable changes in gene function that occur via the modification of DNA sequence such as methylation. Can these hyper-or hypo-methylated biomarkers persist to the next generation? Evidence is also accumulating that ncRNAs (Brander et al. 2017) and histone modification (Gavery & Roberts, 2017) expression and chromatin structure of associated genes that ultimately affects the adaptive strategy and phenotypic traits of the organism.

We provided the first study of changes in DNA methylation profile of oyster larvae in response to ocean acidification (OA) using one of the commercially important edible oyster species as model. Through

Methyl-RAD method, low pH stress associated with OA has been shown to impact the CpG methylation state in larval DNA after three weeks of exposure, resulting a total of 130 hyper-and hypo-methylated genes. CpG methylated sites were found to concentrate in the exon region within the gene bodies, which suggests that the differentially methylated genes may also have altered gene activity profile. In general, differential methylation of genes were involved in cytoskeletal and signal transduction, oxidative stress, lipid and amino acid metabolism, carbohydrate metabolic process, and metamorphosis. This implies the capability of Crassostrea hongkongensis larvae to acclimate and adapt to low pH 7.4 exposure within a single generation despite higher proportion of larvae chose poor habitat for attachment under OA. The differential methylation in the larval genes may have accounted for the higher metamorphosis success rate and poor larval substratum selection in oysters under ocean acidification-derived stress.

FIGREF9.text: caused by low pH is evidenced with the differential methylation in a total of six known genes related to the ubiquitination of proteins, including the hypermethylation of exon-level E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase znrf3. A previous study found an up-regulation trend in transcriptomic response of ubiquitin-related genes such as Ubiquitin-like modifier-activating enzyme 1, E3 ubiquitinprotein ligase SHPRH, UBR4, HRD1 and ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme E2 in C. gigas larvae (Dineshram, 2015). These likely suggest a closely linked association of hypermethylation at exon region and upregulation of genes related to protein ubiquitination under ocean acidification stress. Similar proteins related to ubiquitination were expressed in the geoduck clam larvae under pH 7.5(Timmins-   Schiffman et al., 2019). It is interesting to note that heat-shock related proteins, which commonly are triggered by wide-array type of stressors were not found differentially methylated under the influence of reduced pH. Consistent with Dineshram et al. (2013)'s study on C. hongkongensis pediveliger larvae under low pH, heat shock proteins were not differentially expressed on the proteome level. This implies the highly plausible capacity of the larvae to acclimate to low pH without involving the addition or removal of CH 3 group in DNA nor going through proteolysis.

This includes the hypo-methylation of NADH dehydrogenase (ubiquinone) iron-sulfur protein 2, a gene related to mitochondrial ATP synthesis for energy production.A hypomethylation here suggests a possible upward shift in reaction rate of the methyl group in the gene regions related to amino acid and lipid metabolisms as compared to those related to metabolic metabolism. In other words, the contrasting trend of differential methylation indicates that the catabolism of amino acids and lipid may act as the alternative energy production role in C. hongkongensis larvae to cope up with ocean acidification in replacement of carbohydrate metabolic pathways. A proteomic study revealed an upregulation of isobutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase, a protein involved in catalyzing branched-chain amino acids leads to increased oxidation of fatty acids and energy production during ocean acidification stressinduced metabolic activity of C. hongkongensis larvae (Dineshram et al. 2013). In geoduck clam larvae, high metabolic shift of proteins related to glucose and fatty acid was evidenced under low pH 7.5 (Timmins-Schiffman et al. 2019), in contrast to the carbohydrate metabolism and gluconeogenesis-related proteins in C. gigas that were expressed in low abundance regardless of pH conditions (Timmins-Schiffman et al. 2014). Larval metamorphosis in oysters involves the transformation of a swimming larvae to benthic sessile stage adult attached to a substrate. The development of an organ, such as a foot, and a dark eyespot during the pediveliger stage implies the high competence to metamorphose and attach on a substrate surface.
